content: The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans under certain conditions. Services covered may include care for a dependent while the homeless veteran receives services from the grant recipient. Partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness. Section 2022A of Title 38, United States Code, authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The Secretary can fund general legal services for these individuals through these partnerships, subject to the availability of funds. The Secretary ensures partnerships for legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness are distributed equitably across the US, including rural areas and tribal lands. Native American and tribal organization definitions are provided in this context. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness include housing-related legal assistance, family law support, and income support services. Legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness include assistance in court proceedings for family reunification, child support, divorce, estate planning, income support, obtaining public benefits, criminal defense related to homelessness issues, and other legal services deemed necessary by the Secretary. The Secretary may require periodic reports on legal services provided to homeless veterans and consult with public and private entities for assistance in identifying organizations for partnerships. The Secretary may require periodic reports on legal services provided to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness through partnerships. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 20 of the title. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Expansion of Department of Veterans Affairs authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to extend eligibility for care to veterans enrolled under section 1705(a) receiving housing assistance or care in specified settings for 60 consecutive days. The Department of Veterans Affairs can provide dental care to homeless veterans in specific settings for 60 consecutive days, including domiciliaries, therapeutic residences, community residential care, and settings funded by the Secretary for grant and per diem providers. The Department of Veterans Affairs can provide dental care to homeless veterans for 60 consecutive days, with breaks in care disregarded if the veteran is not responsible. The text chunk discusses the repeal of the sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness transitioning from certain institutions, and the extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. SEC. 6. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. Amendment to section 2044(e) of title 38, United States Code includes an increase to $500,000,000 for fiscal year 2017. Training entities for provision of supportive services are extended through 2017. SEC. 7. Requirement for Comptroller General to study Department of Veterans Affairs homeless veterans programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on Department of Veterans Affairs programs for homeless veterans within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The study will assess program effectiveness for eligible veterans and review efforts to enhance privacy, safety, and security for female veterans. SEC. 8. REPEAL OF REQUIREMENT FOR ANNUAL REPORTS ON ASSISTANCE TO HOMELESS VETERANS. Section 2065 of title 38, United States Code, is repealed. The table of sections in chapter 20 of such title is amended accordingly.
